articles.title: ESA spaceplane project revives bankrupt firm’s hypersonic engine
articles.description: A bankrupt company’s propulsion system for hypersonic planes is being revived by Invictus, a new European Space Agency (ESA)-backed project aiming to build and fly a hydrogen-powered spaceplane by 2031. The proposed engine for the plane is based on so-called pre-cooler technology, developed over decades by UK aerospace firm Reaction Engines, which went bust in November. Many of Reaction Engines’ top engineers found a new home at British aerospace and defence company Frazer-Nash Consultancy,...
articles.author: Siôn Geschwindt
articles.content: A bankrupt company’s propulsion system for hypersonic planes is being revived by Invictus, a new European Space Agency (ESA)-backed project aiming to build and fly a hydrogen-powered spaceplane by 2031. The proposed engine for the plane is based on so-called pre-cooler technology, developed over decades by UK aerospace firm Reaction Engines, which went bust in November. Many of Reaction Engines’ top engineers found a new home at British aerospace and defence company Frazer-Nash Consultancy,...

articles.title: Exclusive: German startup takes on ‘solar-only’ rivals with energy-as-a-service model
articles.description: German startup Enerkii has launched an energy-as-a-service model that aims to cut power bills in half for industrial customers — and decarbonise them in the process. The model uses an in-house operating system (OS) to calculate the optimal solar energy configuration for any company in around 15 minutes. Then it provides the hardware stack to set it up — solar panels, battery storage, EV charging, and, soon, heat pumps. Henrik Abel, co-founder of Enerkii, said the approach shifts from simply...
articles.author: Siôn Geschwindt
articles.content: German startup Enerkii has launched an energy-as-a-service model that aims to cut power bills in half for industrial customers — and decarbonise them in the process. articles.title: LangGraph 101: What Every AI Engineer Should Know
articles.description: 💡 “Ever wondered how an AI assistant can decide what to do next, like a human?”Source: imgflipBehind the scenes, most LLM apps follow a linear flow — input in, output out. But real-world tasks aren’t always linear. They involve loops, decisions, retries, and memory.That’s where LangGraph shines.In this beginner-friendly guide, you’ll learn:What LangGraph is and why it’s differentHow to build your first graph-based agentHow nodes, edges, and state fit togetherReal code examples with...
articles.author: Aayushi_Sharma

articles.title: UK’s best AI engineers can apply now to build tech for public services in $1 million fellowship
articles.description: The UK government, backed by a $1 million Meta grant to the Alan Turing Institute, is launching a 12-month Open-Source AI Fellowship to bring top AI experts into government to build open-source AI tools that improve public services, boost productivity, and support national security.
articles.content: The UK government, backed by a $1 million Meta grant to the Alan Turing Institute, is launching a 12-month Open-Source AI Fellowship to bring top AI experts into government to build open-source AI tools that improve public services, boost productivity, and support national security.

articles.title: Building enterprise-scale RAG applications with Amazon S3 Vectors and DeepSeek R1 on Amazon SageMaker AI
articles.description: Organizations are adopting large language models (LLMs), such as DeepSeek R1, to transform business processes, enhance customer experiences, and drive innovation at unprecedented speed. However, standalone LLMs have key limitations such as hallucinations, outdated knowledge, and no access to proprietary data. Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) addresses these gaps by combining semantic search with generative AI, […]
articles.author: Sandeep Raveesh-Babu

articles.title: AI-Powered Math Tutoring: Platform for Personalized and Adaptive Education
articles.description: arXiv:2507.12484v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The growing ubiquity of artificial intelligence (AI), in particular large language models (LLMs), has profoundly altered the way in which learners gain knowledge and interact with learning material, with many claiming that AI positively influences their learning achievements. Despite this advancement, current AI tutoring systems face limitations associated with their reactive nature, often providing direct answers without encouraging deep...

articles.title: CT-ScanGaze: A Dataset and Baselines for 3D Volumetric Scanpath Modeling
articles.description: arXiv:2507.12591v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Understanding radiologists' eye movement during Computed Tomography (CT) reading is crucial for developing effective interpretable computer-aided diagnosis systems. However, CT research in this area has been limited by the lack of publicly available eye-tracking datasets and the three-dimensional complexity of CT volumes. To address these challenges, we present the first publicly available eye gaze dataset on CT, called CT-ScanGaze. Then, we...
articles.author: Trong-Thang Pham, Akash Awasthi, Saba Khan, Esteban Duran Marti, Tien-Phat Nguyen, Khoa Vo, Minh Tran, Ngoc Son Nguyen, Cuong Tran Van, Yuki Ikebe, Anh Totti Nguyen, Anh Nguyen, Zhigang Deng, Carol C. Wu, Hien Van Nguyen, Ngan Le
articles.content: arXiv:2507.12591v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Understanding radiologists' eye movement during Computed Tomography (CT) reading is crucial for developing effective interpretable computer-aided diagnosis systems. However, CT research in this area has been limited by the lack of publicly available eye-tracking datasets and the three-dimensional complexity of CT volumes. To address these challenges, we present the first publicly available eye gaze dataset on CT, called CT-ScanGaze. Then, we...

articles.title: Cybersecurity’s global alarm system is breaking down
articles.description: Every day, billions of people trust digital systems to run everything from communication to commerce to critical infrastructure. But the global early warning system that alerts security teams to dangerous software flaws is showing critical gaps in coverage—and most users have no idea their digital lives are likely becoming more vulnerable. Over the past 18…

articles.title: Scientists reportedly hiding AI text prompts in academic papers to receive positive peer reviews
articles.description: Research papers found carrying hidden white text giving instructions not to highlight negatives as concern grows over use of large language models for peer reviewAcademics are reportedly hiding prompts in preprint papers for artificial intelligence tools, encouraging them to give positive reviews.Nikkei reported on 1 July it had reviewed research papers from 14 academic institutions in eight countries, including Japan, South Korea, China, Singapore and two in the United States.
